newsitem.title: UK: Mideast/west VLCCs firm, other tankers mainly flat.
newsitem.headline: Mideast/west VLCCs firm, other tankers mainly flat.

text.p: Middle East/West very large crude carrier (VLCC) rates dipped on Wednesday but held steady to most other destinations, brokers said.
They said the 280,000 tonne Macoma was snapped up at a soft W52.5 for a Mideast/U.S. Gulf-U.K./Cont voyage for KPC, loading April 24, well below the previous prevailing rate of W60.
"There are not enough cargoes and more vessels after (April) 15," said a U.S. broker. "I have seen three Korean relets, all modern tonnage, for April 20-25...The Macoma went very fast."
Mideast/Japan rates were unchanged at W67.5, with Mideast/Singapore also flat at W60/62.5, depending on vessel quality.
The West Africa VLCC market was quiet, but brokers said the rate remained around W72.5, with 130,000 tonners steady at W97.5 for an older ship and W102.5 for a modern vessel.

Cross-Mediterranean 80,000 tonne cargoes firmed to W140 from W120, while the 130,000 tonne sector was steady and quiet at W100. "A lot of Aframaxes (80,000 tonners) have disappeared for Easter and there are a lot of cargoes," an Italian broker said.

Caribs/upoast 70,000 tonne crude, which has surged in recent weeks, appeared to have reached a plateau at W235/240, brokers said. "It's as high as it has been for a couple of years, and I don't see it going much higher," one added.
But Caribs 50,000 tonne fuel oil cargoes firmed to W225 from W212.5 with owners prepared to pay out to move early cargoes, they said.
In the inter-U.K./Cont sector, Aframaxes were steady at W140, up some 25 points over the last three weeks.
Fuel oil in UKC edged down to W200 from W205 for 20,000 tonnes, while in the Med it was steady at W210.
